ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had weekly class discussions in addition to our TF discussion section.
2 recorded lectures per week, plus one live virtual lecture and one live virtual section per week
Recorded Lecture and Discussion section with TA and student
Virtual discussion section
Weekly 30 min online class for discussion, and weekly sections
The class had one in-class session, one discussion section, and two short recorded lectures per week.
Recorded lectures (twice per week), once per week full-class checkin (~30 minutes), and one section
There were two recorded lectures and two synchronous meetings for each week. One meeting was with the professor, and the other was with a TA.
live virtual lecture, virtual discussion section

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned how to reconcile different aspects of Southern history and culture through studying a wide array of literature and historical texts.
How to read analytically and make connections and find meaningful differences between books on similar topics
Before taking this course I was very unfamiliar with the southern Literature genre. This course has enabled me to learn about a wide range of themes and topics in stories I have otherwise not seen.
I learned about the South! Really cool

I learned about the history of the South from the 1830s to Reconstruction, as well as historical myths and ways of viewing the American South. Major themes were what makes up a Southern Gothic and the contradicting elements of Southern society/politics.
I gained both close reading skills and an ability to view a various works of Southern literature through the lens of a more unified cultural theory
I learned so much about how the American South came to be and how Southerners imagined their world through literature. I also learned how to close read intricate passages.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the mix of recorded lecture and virtual live discussions to both learn at my own pace but also check in with my professor and peers.

Prof. Smith is a funny, intelligent, and engaging class leader, and the texts he selected for the syllabus made for interesting reads. The class was relatively low-stress, and the format worked well for virtual learning. I will say though that I got a bit of conflicting feedback from my TF and the professor on some of the coursework, so that did introduce a little confusion in completing assignments.

This course was very helpful in that it gave a lot of time for student lead discussions. This enabled me to have stronger ideas for my essays. I was also able to ask about topics that I did not understand which in turn gave me a better understanding of the stories as a whole and about specific themes.
Professor Smith's lectures are actually so good!!

One strength of this course was the sheer amount of material that we read, much of which I never would have read in my own time. However, this was also a weakness -- we read so much that there were many works that we barely discussed that I would have liked to discuss more. Also, there were many themes/symbols that were brought up once or twice that I would have liked to focus more on.

The readings were pretty lopsided, meaning some weeks had MUCH more than others, which made it difficult to carve out a consistent space in my week for the work in this class. But the lectures are riveting and the selected works wonderful, and the assignment structure was not overwhelming at all.

The reading list is great. In this particular semester, though, I felt that the discussion posts were just too much and didn't really contribute to learning in any significant way (at least not enough to be worth the added time/effort/stress of posting each week).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The format Prof. Rogers employed worked well for the virtual set up.

The pre-recorded lectures worked well paired with the once weekly in person meeting. It let me learn on my own time while also giving a sense of connection with the rest of the class and the professor.
This course was pretty successful in its changes for the pandemic. The virtual discussion sections were easy to be engaged in.
Professor switched to prerecorded lectures which was nice. It was also good to have all of that for review.

I liked that there was only one class-wide lecture per week and two shorter recorded lectures, rather than having two class-wide meetings per week. I think that the weekly class meetings could be more structured because there were a few times (especially in the beginning) where there was silence for a prolonged period of time.

I found that the full-class discussions were either unnecessary or redundant (i.e. of either the recorded lecture or of section). I also selected a section later in the week so I could do the reading later in the week because my schedule was lopsided, but the full-class meetings on Wednesdays made this impossible (or made me feel unprepared when I didnt manage to finish the reading).

I really liked the recorded lectures! Being able to pause/slow down/etc. allowed me to take more thorough notes and made exam prep easier. The discussion posts were not very helpful, though; it just felt like busy work that added unnecessary stress/time/effort when discussion sections already serve the same purpose, especially in a semester where most everyone was just trying to get through as best they could.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! It was an English course that I really enjoyed, and I am typically not the biggest fan of English courses.

I'd recommend this course to a peer who is interested in literature of the South; without this investment, the reading list won't be as exciting. However, Prof. Smith is an absolute gem, and I loved learning under him.
I would recommend this course for students interested in literature. Otherwise, it may be a lot to handle.
Absolutely! Not an easy class especially if your major doesn't have anything to do with the humanities, but you can learn so much!
I would recommend this course to another student only if they have enough time to/are invested in reading all the class material.

Yes! I would definitely recommend this course. Its one of the few Yale courses that really studies the South, and does so through the lens of Southern cultural studies (rather than merely American history or close reading). It allows students to build a coherent (though flexible) conception of the social structure of the South, which is helpful in all different kinds of work.
I would recommend this course to any student! It was really interesting and I think I'm going to take a lot away from it.

extras.title:
ENGL 187 01/AMST 239 01
        Love & Hate in the South
